title.narrative: Uganda Coffee Communities: Promoting Child Education

description.narrative: While Uganda has legislation and policies on child labor, including a National Action Plan, enforcement is weak, limiting their effectiveness. The US Department of Labor estimates that 30% of the population of children aged 5-14 are working, 88.7% of those children are attending school and 34.4% are combining school and work. 95.4% of working children aged 5-14 work in agriculture including cultivating and harvesting coffee. The root causes of child labour are complex; the partners’ studies and experience have shown that the causes of child labour in coffee growing communities in Uganda include: poverty, harmful traditional practices like early child marriage, absence of schools or inadequate schools and infrastructure, demotivated and lack of teachers, illiteracy of parents or guardians, and a lack of parent and caretaker awareness.In the Rwenzori region (3,000 households), partners will implement an area-based approach towards the creation of Child Labour Free Zones (CLFZ) with gender specific economic resilience interventions and supply chain approaches. In the Masaka region (1,100 households) Project A will determine the best approach, given the unique geographical with larger commercial coffee farms spread out over a large area.Rainforest Alliance will work at the community level in the coffee regions of Greater Masaka and Rwenzori, in coffee value chains that are UTZ Certified (and will be Rainforest Alliance Certified in the future). Our approach is collaborative, actively involving all stakeholders including coffee exporter staff, teachers, parents, children, teacher unions, community groups, local authorities and employers to work together to develop and implement a program to end all forms of child labour in the area. Our project will address root causes related to lack of access to quality education, poverty and harmful traditional practices by raising awareness, showcasing the value of education and reducing poverty by improving income from coffee and other sources.
